Review:
It's rare but every now and then you find one of those special games that you know will stay with you, and Stray was one of them for me. Man, I don't even know where to start. The game is truly beautiful, I had to keep stopping just to snap screenshots. The story is emotionally beautiful (I might say beautiful a lot but oh well, describes the game perfectly  ¯\_(ツ)_/¯) and it was just an enjoyable and beautiful experience from start to finish. 

No bugs or stutters, played perfectly on a middle of the road PC and you can tell there was so much love and care put into making this game. I'm not usually a fan of stealth but actually had fun with it in Stray when it came to those little stealth sections. This review is all over the place because I'm still emotional after finishing this BEAUTIFUL game.
A great game to play in the face of societal collapse. Sometimes very sad, but somehow very optimistic, too.

If you enjoy immersive worlds, exploration, problem solving, a little sci-fi dystopia, and cats, then this is everything you could want. Stray is a touching story wrapped in a beautiful world experienced though a novel character. Take it from another feline, this is an excellent game for fellow feline aficionados out there.

In [i]Stray[/i], you control an adorable ginger cat who strays from its herd and stumbles into an underground city. Originally built by humans to survive a post-apocalyptic future, the city now feels abandoned—populated only by quirky robots and mutant bacteria. Your mission is to navigate this eerie world and find your way back to the surface with the help of an insomniac robot companion.

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]

[i]Stray[/i] is a cinematic third-person adventure that blends exploration, stealth, action, and horror.

The standout feature is its feline protagonist, whose natural limitations shape every aspect of the gameplay. As a cat, you can’t reach wall-mounted controls, carry most items, or engage in combat. Instead, interactions rely on your versatile robot companion, who picks up objects, opens doors and containers, and translates signs and speech. Although switching between the cat and the robot is seamless, moments when the robot is unavailable emphasize just how helpless the cat can be without its companion.

[h3]Presentation[/h3]

Powered by Unreal Engine 4, [i]Stray[/i] looks nice and runs well—even on a Steam Deck. The game presents a clear contrast: on one hand, cute, exaggerated character designs, and on the other, a bleak, dystopian environment with aspects of cosmic horror. Separately, the crisp lighting and vibrant colors set the mood and guide you effectively through the world.

[h3]Story[/h3]

[i]Stray[/i] weaves together several narratives: a dystopian tale of humanity’s self-destruction, an existential journey of robot slaves in a post-human world, and the personal quest of a robot regaining lost memories. The cat serves primarily as the player vehicle, while the story focuses on the robot companion and the city.

In my experience, the narrative is easy to follow and well-paced, with the most compelling moments emerging from subtle insights into the everyday lives of the robots and the environmental storytelling. However, I felt that the broader human downfall and the robot’s personal journey sometimes came across as underdeveloped and emotionally distant.

[h3]Replay Value[/h3]

At a premium price of $30, [i]Stray[/i] is a relatively short experience that can be completed over the course of an evening. While the cat’s size and vertical movement options create an illusion of a vast world, most areas are small and offer next to no optional content. Although some action sequences allow you to spare enemies, these choices have no impact on the overall story or game world. Ultimately, despite its unique charm, the game offers little reason to replay it beyond revisiting its distinctive world.

Such a unique, exploration game that is a true hidden gem. I recommend this game to any person who loves single-player, open-world games. As for my trophy hunters out there, this game some difficult trophies, but they can be obtained in about 8-10 hours of gameplay. My only real concern is the subpar ending, in which I felt empty and sad. No answers, no visuals to my imagination of what the outside looks like, just a short cliffhanger-like cutscene. Be WARNED: The game starts sad and ends sad.

Issues: There is an issue that has been unsolved for years where when you break down one of the paintings in Momo's house, it will glitch you outside the map. There is also a glitch where one of the memories in "The Sewers" chapter is unobtainable if your fps is "Uncapped." It essentially won't let you walk pass an invisible barrier inside of the tube/tunnel. The achievement "Can't Cat-ch me" is by far the most difficult and many players will struggle with its' RNG like outcome. 

Fix: Set your frames to 60 fps or lower to fix the wall glitch and "The Sewers" glitch. To maximize the ease of getting the achievement, simply lower your frames to 30 fps and zigzag your way through the Zurks. (There are a couple YouTube videos on common glitches inside of the game)

This is one of the most unique, visually pleasing, and heartwarming games I've played in a long time. Though it doesn't delve to deeply into lore or philosophy, it manages to tell a compelling story that asks surprisingly profound questions about the nature of identity, hope, and friendship---all while centering on a feline protagonist who can't communicate except by meowing and clawing things. It's made me reflect on my own friendships, including with my cats, who don't seem to understand what exactly made me so emotional when the game's credits rolled but were right there to comfort me anyway.

I would recommend this game to just about anyone, not just people with a softspot for cats or an interest in sci-fi dystopias. It's a brilliant work of art that provides a meaningful experience, and it's well worth the cost despite its short length. Even after just finishing it I'm eager to dive back in and find more sheet music for Morusque to play on his jerry can guitar and to curl up among the cushions in Clementine's loft for a little longer. It's these small moments that really make it special, the moments of rest and meditation that are an essential complement to the game's story elements and action sequences. 

As I finished the game I was reminded of a quote from John Gray's book Feline Philosophy: "Humans cannot become cats. Yet if they set aside any notion of being superior beings, they may come to understand how cats can thrive without anxiously inquiring how to live." This game, which puts the player in control of a small feline amidst the ruins of a man-made world still rife with humanity's troubles even in the absence of human beings, offers an opportunity to seek the understanding Gray suggests.

There is a lot we can learn from cats that is easy for us to lose sight of, has hectic and stressful as human life can be. The quiet hours spent in relaxation, play, and curiosity are just as important as the time we spend working towards a paycheck or some other goal. Can you imagine a cat "on the grind?" Of course not. Because cats understand innately that you don't need wealth or achievement to get what matters out of life. Sometimes all you need is an inquisitive mind, a friend to play with, or just a soft pillow to curl up on for a nice, long nap.

What an incredible experience this story-based adventure puzzle game was. I laughed, I cried, I smiled, and at times, I even raged a bit. In Stray, you play as a cat who gets separated from his other cat friends with an end goal of making it back to the outside. You will wander through a dilapidated dystopian society, making friends with the inhabitants and even helping them out along the way. As you walk through the neighborhoods, city, and "Zurk zones", you will learn about how society got this way, where the humans went, and about the lives of those around you. The puzzles in this game are fairly intuitive and I never really found myself getting turned around a lot despite the slightly open-world element of some areas of the game. The story is definitely the focus of this game and I would also like to highlight how incredibly beautiful the design of this game is. The art style, the environment, the graphics, how you can interact with your surroundings, and the connections you make throughout this game is really just a nice cherry on top of an overall excellent experience. I truly do feel like this is something everyone should try to play, even if just for the story and art style alone.

Game is okay. Graphics and music are great. Sound effects are also on point, which is important since as a cat you make a lot of cat-like sounds. Story is alright, although like most story-based games I play, I wish there was more lore at the end of the game talking about or showing what happens to everyone. 

Gameplay is being a cat and exploring the world, as well as a few chase sequences. The cat things you do, like meowing and scratching and running in front of other people, is very funny but mostly does nothing for advancing the story. The big thing that being a cat enables is jumping on different platforms to reach a destination. The jumpable places are not immediately obvious, but once you develop an eye for which environmental objects are jumpable then navigating the world is easier. There's also some collectables and sidequests if you like the worldbuilding and exploration.

Also, I got into this game expecting a comfy cat game, and for 80% of the game that's true. For the other 20% that's more intense, I was thrown off by them, with one place in particular stopping me in my tracks. "Why am I here in this place, doing this thing? Where's my cute cat game about doing cute cat things?"

In the end, I still had fun with this game. But in the end, I wouldn't call this game a cat game where you do cat things. I'd say this is a game about exploring a sci-fi-ish, cyberpunky world from the perspective of a cat. I do recommend it though. Also remember to check the game settings before you start the game, for some people there may be some settings default to off that you may want to turn on.

For context I played this game to take a break from World of Warcraft classic. And it delivered; I loved Stray, its a really chill game, you play as a cat, the graphics are stunning, what more could you want? Apart from more that is, this game has great quality but is quite short and left me wanting more to explore. Read on:
P.S: I missed the detail before playing it’s post-apocalyptic and some viewers may find the game terrifying in parts!

Pros: 
Engrossing, easy to follow storyline.
Engaging puzzles, problem solving and friendly npcs.
Beautiful atmosphere and environment design.
Really nice backing soundtracks.
Smooth gameplay, easy to control, user friendly.
Freedom to explore, smash pots, push things off tables and ledges, find secrets and uncover hidden memories.
You’re a cat.
Your lil guide is lovable, helpful, has its own lore and doesn't yell “hey!” 

Cons:
No camera distance option.
No zone or world map.
Not a lot of combat, more fleeing from danger (not a lot of that either relative to play-time).
The one weapon you get is short-lived. 
Limited cat movement (no jumping without a prompt somewhere).
Would like to find more secrets, easter eggs, achievements and overall more content for players like me turning it upside down in curiosity.

Story line:
I find it hard to stay focused on complex lore and story but found this really interesting and easy to follow. You get the story from your guide and npcs in speech bubbles, each giving some background / clue / objective all in one, well worded to keep you on track without reading paragraphs so you can play the game.

Gameplay:
Controlling the character is easy to grasp (not many controls). Would have liked more, like the ability to jump without a prompt to jump somewhere in the environment. You can meow with button which is a fun perk, but for tactical use its only used for one or two puzzles. 
Joystick and camera pivot work really well, camera sensitivity can be adjusted. One nitpick I have is you can’t change the POV distance - coming from a 3rd person MMO I found myself impulsively trying to scroll out. Also, when I used the 1st person look button it didn't always focus on what I was trying to zoom in on. But by default, the POV works well for the gameplay.
A minimap (or any map) would have been really useful. I confess to being bad at navigation and found myself running in circles or down the same streets over again trying to remember where I was trying to get to. 
I love that you can interact by pushing objects in the environment, I got into trying to smash every plant pot hoping there might be an achievement (either I didn't smash enough or there isn’t one). Again, there isn’t really an interact action when not prompted - it would be fun to be able to pick up or paw random objects.
The graphics and projected textures are really good. The world seems full of clues and remnants of what happened, drawing the player deeper into the story and wanting to find out more. The gradient and atmosphere are designed so thoughtfully that you get a sense of either tension, calm or imminent danger just from the tone, subtle colour and light change, as well as the backing sound. 
The audio also is really well thought out, not too loud and overbearing, and suiting the various moods perfectly throughout the game.
Combat: There isn't a lot of this. Much of the game is based around the story and fleeing or dodging danger. You do get one weapon in the game, but this is short lived and seems hardly worth to effort your little cat went through to acquire. And when you get it, it has a limit to how long you can use it until it overheats. Then it breaks for good. Once gotten, I thought “this would of been real useful back there” followed by “I could really use that right now!”.
This game would benefit from having more combat, more puzzle solving levels in general, and more means of self defense - whether that be a more permanent weapon or cat physics (bite and claw). Majority of the time it spent feeling pretty helpless before your foes. 

Verdict:
I absolutely loved playing this game. It’s beautifully designed and well-thought out for the player. The story is easy and really engaging to follow. There’s scope to explore and stray from the main path, however the game would benefit from more secrets and easter eggs, side-quests and hidden achievements. All in all it’s a really good quality game, for me it took roughly 10-12 hours to finish (I’m not a speed gamer and like to explore). Where it’s lacking is not in quality, but in quantity, which isn’t the worst thing a game can offer! What you get to play is a fun, casual, engaging game where you play as a cat on a mission. Highly recommend this to anyone thinking of playing it.

There’s something about Stray that hits differently. It’s not just a game. It’s an experience. You step into the paws of a small, lost cat, wandering through a city that simultaneously feels alive and wholly abandoned. It’s eerie yet beautiful. Quiet yet filled with stories waiting to be found.
At first, you’re just trying to find your way back home. But as you explore, you realise you’re not just a stray cat but part of something bigger. You meet robots who long for a world they never got to see, a little drone companion who becomes your only friend, and remnants of a past that feels distant but strangely familiar.
There were moments when I just stopped. I sat on rooftops, watching neon signs flicker in the distance. I curled up next to a lonely musician, letting the soft sound of their guitar fill the air. I knocked over bottles and scratched at rugs because why not? Every detail made the world feel real, like I was there.
But what surprised me the most was how human this story felt. Even without words, Stray tells a tale of loss, companionship, and hope. It reminded me there’s always a reason to keep going, even in the loneliest places.
And then the credits rolled. And I just sat there, not ready to leave, not ready to say goodbye. Because sometimes, a game isn’t just pixels and mechanics; it’s a feeling, a memory, a story that becomes part of you.
And Stray? I’ll carry it with me for a long, long time.

[h1]Stray – The Catspiracy is Real[/h1]
I used to think my cat was just a cute, clueless ball of fur. Then I played Stray. Now I sleep with one eye open, fearing the day he hacks my Wi-Fi and leads a robot uprising. This game turns you into a tiny feline parkour master in a cyberpunk world, solving puzzles, outsmarting machines, and knocking over perfectly placed bottles—just because you can. It’s gorgeous, emotional, and a little too convincing.

Verdict: 10/10, my cat is plotting something, and I’m scared. 🐱🤖

Stray is a game that captured my attention from start to finish, offering a unique and heartfelt experience that stands out in the gaming landscape. Without diving into spoilers, I can say the story is one of the game’s strongest elements. It’s thoughtfully crafted, drawing you in with its emotional beats and leaving you pondering long after the credits roll. The environments are equally captivating, with every corner of the neon-lit city brimming with detail and atmosphere. It’s a world that feels alive, even in its decay, and I loved every moment spent exploring it.

Playing as a cat in Stray is an experience that feels both refreshing and endearing. The design of the cat itself is fantastic, and while some animations felt a little off at times, it didn’t take away from the gameplay. In fact, these quirks occasionally made me laugh, adding charm to the experience. One feature I absolutely loved was the ability to meow freely—even during cutscenes! It’s such a small detail, but it added so much personality and lighthearted fun to the game.

The gameplay is another highlight, especially the “parkour”-style movement system. As a cat, you can leap to countless places, climb rooftops, and traverse areas in ways that feel uniquely feline. However, I did find it a bit restrictive that you couldn’t jump freely unless there was a designated surface to jump to. A regular jump mechanic, like in many other games, would have added an extra layer of freedom to the experience. That said, it’s a small minus in an otherwise fluid and enjoyable system.

The interactions with the game’s other characters were another element I appreciated. Every character you encounter feels meaningful, with their own purpose and personality. While the protagonist doesn’t speak, the depth given to the friendly characters really stands out, adding emotional weight and connection to the story.

The puzzles struck a great balance for me. They were challenging enough to make me think but not so hard that they became frustrating. The variety of difficulty—from easier puzzles to trickier ones—kept the game engaging throughout, especially if, like me, you enjoy completing 100% of a game.


Overall, Stray was an enjoyable journey that left me wanting more. I couldn’t help but wish for a longer game or even major side stories separate from the main plot—something with its own depth and challenges to expand on this beautifully built world. That said, the game excels at what it sets out to do: delivering a memorable, heartfelt experience in a way that only a cat’s perspective could.

[h3] Graphics and Atmosphere [/h3]
Visually, Stray is breathtaking. The developers at BlueTwelve Studio have created a decayed yet fascinating cyberpunk world, where neon lights blend with dark alleys and abandoned streets. Every corner of the city tells a story, and the attention to detail is impressive—from the way the cat moves and grooms itself to the reactions of robotic NPCs to its interactions.

[h3] Immersive Gameplay [/h3]
The gameplay experience is incredibly smooth and realistic. The feline protagonist’s movements are strikingly authentic: jumping between platforms, rubbing against robots, scratching carpets, and meowing at will are all elements that make the immersion total. The balance between exploration, environmental puzzles, and stealth sections creates the perfect mix of relaxation and tension.

[h3] Story and Narrative [/h3]
Despite the protagonist being a cat and unable to speak, Stray manages to tell a deep and emotional story. The bond with B-12, the small drone accompanying the player, develops naturally and touchingly. The mystery behind the city and its inhabitants gradually unfolds, allowing for moments that are both sweet and melancholic.

[h3]Soundtrack and Sound Design[/h3]
The soundtrack is perfect for the game’s atmosphere—delicate, engaging electronic melodies accompany the exploration, enhancing the most emotional moments. The sound design is also exceptional, with realistic effects that bring the world and protagonist to life: the sound of paws on different surfaces, the meows, and even the purring all contribute to making everything feel even more authentic.

Stray is more than just a game; it is an artistic and narrative experience that deserves to be played. Perfect for cat lovers, but also for anyone looking for a unique, touching, and visually stunning adventure.
